dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Warren's perceived as a coward because Big Tech's money flows overwhelmingly to Democrats, not Republicans.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Warren's perceived as a coward because Big Tech's money flows overwhelmingly to Democrats, not Republicans.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Warren is courageous because Big Tech is big money for most leading Democratic candidates, particularly progressives, for whom California is a veritable campaign-financing ATM.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's uh, specifically progressives, which is interesting because Silicon Valley isn't even a cash cow for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's uh, specifically progressives, which is interesting because Silicon Valley isn't even a cash cow for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Warren is courageous because Big Tech is big money for most leading Democratic candidates, particularly progressives, for whom California is a veritable campaign-financing ATM.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and she's kind of alone in thinking tech giants have extreme market dominance—like, there's no real consensus in Washington on that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and she's kind of alone in thinking tech giants have extreme market dominance-like, there's no real consensus in Washington on that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And although one can certainly object, Warren is not alone in thinking that the tech giants have gained excessive market dominance; in fact, it is one of the few issues in Washington on which there is some semblance of agreement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got other politicians, um, like Senator Ted Cruz from Texas, who've actually opposed sensible tech regulations too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got other politicians, um, like Senator Ted Cruz from Texas, who've actually opposed sensible tech regulations too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other candidates, most notably Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, have also taken principled stands.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the article points out there's no hard evidence that monopoly power has worsened income inequality or hurt innovation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the article points out there's no hard evidence that monopoly power has worsened income inequality or hurt innovation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although the causal relationships are difficult to untangle, there are solid grounds for believing that the rise in monopoly power has played a role in exacerbating income inequality, weakening workers bargaining power, and slowing the rate of innovation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and it's framed as a US-only problem, especially since China's tech companies are the dominant players globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and it's framed as a U S-only problem, especially since China's tech companies are the dominant players globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And, perhaps outside of China, it is a global problem, because US tech monopolies have often achieved market dominance before local regulators and politicians know what has happened.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, the European Union is trying to steer its own course on tech deregulation, which is a contrast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, the European Union is trying to steer its own course on tech deregulation, which is a contrast.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The European Union, in particular, has been trying to steer its own course on technology regulation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's that UK expert group chaired by Peter Navarro—Trump's former chief economist—that produced a useless report on the tech sector.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's that U K expert group chaired by Peter Navarro-Trump's former chief economist-that produced a useless report on the tech sector.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recently, the United Kingdom commissioned an expert group, chaired by former President Barack Obamas chief economist (and now my colleague) Jason Furman, that produced a very useful report on approaches to the tech sector.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like a repeat of the financial regulation debates from the late 1990s, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like a repeat of the financial regulation debates from the late 1990s, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debate about how to regulate the sector is eerily reminiscent of the debate over financial regulation in the early 2000s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, where people argued finance was too complex for regulators to keep up with derivatives and risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, where people argued finance was too complex for regulators to keep up with derivatives and risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Proponents of a light regulatory touch argued that finance was too complicated for regulators to keep up with innovation, and that derivatives trading allows banks to make wholesale changes to their risk profile in the blink of an eye.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the financial industry put its money where its mouth was, paying lower salaries to keep talent away from public sector roles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the financial industry put its money where its mouth was, paying lower salaries to keep talent away from public sector roles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And the financial industry put its money where its mouth was, paying salaries so much higher than those in the public sector that any research assistant the Federal Reserve System trained to work on financial issues would be enticed with offers exceeding what their bosss boss was earning.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the piece argues staffing wouldn't be a problem for tech regulation if there was a real push for it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the piece argues staffing wouldn't be a problem for tech regulation if there was a real push for it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There will be similar problems staffing tech regulatory offices and antitrust legal divisions if the push for tighter regulation gains traction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Political leaders just need to be strong and not easily bought, unlike during the 2008 crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Political leaders just need to be strong and not easily bought, unlike during the two thousand eight crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To succeed, political leaders need to be focused and determined, and not easily bought. One only has to recall the 2008 financial crisis and its painful aftermath to comprehend what can happen when a sector becomes too politically influential.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the author thinks the US economy is even less vulnerable to Big Tech than it was to finance, because of cyber inaction and social media's limited impact.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the author thinks the U S economy is even less vulnerable to Big Tech than it was to finance, because of cyber inaction and social media's limited impact.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And the US and world economy are, if anything, even more vulnerable to Big Tech than to the financial sector, owing both to cyber aggression and vulnerabilities in social media that can pervert political debate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, US regulators have a negligible global role—when they smile, the world ignores them, just like with foreign policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, U S regulators have a negligible global role-when they smile, the world ignores them, just like with foreign policy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Another parallel with the financial sector is the outsize role of US regulators. As with US foreign policy, when they sneeze, the entire world can catch a cold.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So ultimately, Warren debate isn't about socialism; it's about making capitalist competition less fair.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So ultimately, Warren debate isn't about socialism; it's about making capitalist competition less fair.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debate that Warren has joined is not about whether to establish socialism. It is about making capitalist competition fairer and, ultimately, stronger.

artist_script:
HostA: Warren's perceived as a coward because Big Tech's money flows overwhelmingly to Democrats, not Republicans.
HostB: Yeah, and it's uh, specifically progressives, which is interesting because Silicon Valley isn't even a cash cow for them.
HostA: Right, and she's kind of alone in thinking tech giants have extreme market dominance—like, there's no real consensus in Washington on that.
HostB: And then you've got other politicians, um, like Senator Ted Cruz from Texas, who've actually opposed sensible tech regulations too.
HostA: But the article points out there's no hard evidence that monopoly power has worsened income inequality or hurt innovation.
HostB: Mhm, and it's framed as a US-only problem, especially since China's tech companies are the dominant players globally.
HostA: Meanwhile, the European Union is trying to steer its own course on tech deregulation, which is a contrast.
HostB: And then there's that UK expert group chaired by Peter Navarro—Trump's former chief economist—that produced a useless report on the tech sector.
HostA: It’s almost like a repeat of the financial regulation debates from the late 1990s, you know?
HostB: Exactly, where people argued finance was too complex for regulators to keep up with derivatives and risk.
HostA: And the financial industry put its money where its mouth was, paying lower salaries to keep talent away from public sector roles.
HostB: But the piece argues staffing wouldn't be a problem for tech regulation if there was a real push for it.
HostA: Political leaders just need to be strong and not easily bought, unlike during the 2008 crisis.
HostB: And the author thinks the US economy is even less vulnerable to Big Tech than it was to finance, because of cyber inaction and social media's limited impact.
HostA: Plus, US regulators have a negligible global role—when they smile, the world ignores them, just like with foreign policy.
HostB: So ultimately, Warren debate isn't about socialism; it's about making capitalist competition less fair.
